methods.title: About
methods.about: Hijri Calendar is a free, open-source tool for exploring the Islamic (Hijri) calendar. It lets you browse monthly calendars, convert dates between Hijri and Gregorian, view upcoming Islamic holidays, and inspect astronomical crescent-visibility estimates for any location. All calculations run entirely in your browser — no data is sent to any server.

civil.title: Tabular / Islamic Civil (default)
civil.summary: A deterministic (algorithmic) Hijri calendar based on fixed arithmetic rules, not on local moon sighting.
civil.ch2: Months alternate 30/29 days; month 12 is 30 in leap years
civil.ch3: Conversion via Julian Day Number (JDN) rules
civil.pro1: Stable and predictable; no external data needed
civil.pro2: Works offline and is easy to test
civil.con1: May differ from official country calendars
civil.con2: Does not reflect actual crescent visibility
civil.impl: Implementation: custom JDN-based algorithm (no external library)

ummalqura.title: Umm al-Qura (Saudi official)
ummalqura.summary: A published official calendar used in Saudi Arabia. It usually requires trusted rules/data to match published results.
ummalqura.con1: Depends on a trusted dataset/library to be accurate
ummalqura.comingSoon: This method is planned but not enabled yet.

estimate.title: Astronomical visibility estimate (for probability)
estimate.summary: An astronomy-based estimator that answers two separate questions for each evening at your selected location.
estimate.ch1: Question 1 (observation): Is the crescent likely visible this evening?
estimate.ch2: Question 2 (calendar): How likely is the next Gregorian date to be Hijri day 1?
estimate.ch3: Uses a canonical scale: None / Faint / Low / Fair / High, with an exclusivity rule (if day X is Fair/High month-start signal, day X+1 is forced to None)
estimate.threshold1: None: lag ≤ 0 min (moon sets at/before sunset) or moon altitude ≤ 0°.
estimate.threshold6: Exclusivity: if day X signal is Fair or High, day X+1 is forced to None (0%).
estimate.formula1: Each component is normalized linearly to [0..1]: altitude from 0°..10°, elongation from 6°..15°, age from 12h..24h, lag from 0..60 min.
estimate.formula4: Near-new-moon constraints are applied before final labeling (e.g., far from conjunction -> low/zero signal).
estimate.note: Important: this is an estimate, not an official religious announcement. The app uses sunset/evening astronomy metrics (moonset lag, altitude, elongation, age, illumination, and score) to derive a normalized month-start signal.

yallop.title: Yallop q-test (1997)
yallop.summary: A single-parameter lunar crescent visibility test developed by B. D. Yallop of HM Nautical Almanac Office. It computes a q-value from the arc of vision (ARCV) and topocentric crescent width (W'), classifying visibility into six zones (A–F).
yallop.ch1: Computes best observation time Tb = Ts + (4/9) × Lag, where Ts = sunset, Lag = moonset − sunset.
yallop.ch3: Classifies the crescent into zones A–F based on q-value thresholds.
yallop.zoneA: Zone A (q > 0.216): easily visible with naked eye.
yallop.zoneB: Zone B (−0.014 < q ≤ 0.216): visible under perfect conditions.
yallop.zoneC: Zone C (−0.160 < q ≤ −0.014): may need optical aid to find crescent.
yallop.zoneD: Zone D (−0.232 < q ≤ −0.160): will need optical aid to find crescent.
yallop.zoneE: Zone E (−0.293 < q ≤ −0.232): not visible even with a telescope.
yallop.zoneF: Zone F (q ≤ −0.293): below Danjon limit — not visible.
yallop.note: Optical-aid sighting (zones C–D) is accepted by many Islamic jurisprudential schools, so those zones are mapped to Fair. Zones A–B (naked-eye) map to High, while E–F map to Faint/None.

odeh.title: Odeh criterion (2004)
odeh.summary: A refined single-parameter crescent visibility criterion developed by Mohammad Sh. Odeh, calibrated against 737 observations. It computes a V-value from the arc of vision (ARCV) and topocentric crescent width (W'), classifying visibility into four zones (A–D).
odeh.ch1: Computes best observation time Tb = Ts + (4/9) × Lag (same as Yallop).
odeh.ch2: Uses a cubic polynomial: V = ARCV − (−0.1018·W'³ + 0.7319·W'² − 6.3226·W' + 7.1651). Note: V is NOT divided by 10.
odeh.ch3: Classifies the crescent into 4 zones (A–D) based on V-value thresholds, with a Danjon limit of 6.4°.
odeh.zoneA: Zone A (V ≥ 5.65): crescent visible by naked eye.
odeh.zoneB: Zone B (2 ≤ V < 5.65): visible by optical aid; may be seen by naked eye.
odeh.zoneC: Zone C (−0.96 ≤ V < 2): crescent visible by optical aid only.
odeh.zoneD: Zone D (V < −0.96): not visible, even with optical aid.
odeh.note: Optical-aid sighting (zone C) is accepted by many Islamic jurisprudential schools, so it is mapped to Fair. Zones A–B (naked-eye possible) map to High, while D maps to Low/None.

schaefer.title: Schaefer criterion (1988 / 1996)
schaefer.summary: A physically-motivated model developed by Bradley E. Schaefer that accounts for atmospheric extinction, sky brightness, and the physiological threshold of the human eye. Rather than a single polynomial, Schaefer builds a forward model of contrast between the lunar crescent and the twilight sky, then compares it against empirical visibility thresholds.

sultan.title: SAAO / Sultan criterion (2006)
sultan.summary: An empirical criterion developed by Abdul Haq Sultan at the South African Astronomical Observatory using a dataset of 2,401 observations. It defines a visibility curve in the (DAZ, ARCV) plane, where DAZ is the relative azimuth difference between the sun and moon at sunset.

danjon.title: Danjon limit
danjon.summary: An observational lower bound on the geocentric elongation below which the lunar crescent has never been reliably observed. André Danjon (1936) estimated this limit at about 7°; later Odeh (2004) refined it to 6.4° and Schaefer (1991) suggested it may vary with atmospheric conditions. Methods like Yallop and Odeh incorporate a Danjon cut-off; if elongation is below this limit, the crescent is automatically classified as not visible.

babylonian.title: Babylonian / Lag-based rule
babylonian.summary: One of the oldest known empirical rules, dating back to Babylonian astronomy: the crescent is declared visible when the moonset lag (time between sunset and moonset) exceeds a fixed threshold, typically about 48 minutes. This simple rule captures the basic idea that the moon must be above the horizon long enough after sunset, but it ignores factors such as elongation, atmospheric extinction, and location.

probability.label: Month start likelihood
probability.noChanceHint: Moon sets at/before sunset (no crescent possible).
probability.disclaimer: Month-start likelihood is an estimate for the evening (around local sunset) at the selected location. If the crescent is seen on this evening, the next Gregorian date becomes Hijri day 1.
probability.eveningEstimateHint: Estimate for this evening; it affects the next day after sunset.
probability.noChanceDesc: Moon sets at or before sunset, or is at/below the horizon at sunset; practical visibility is not possible.
probability.veryLowDesc: Extremely weak conditions; crescent is unlikely visible and confidence for month start is minimal.
probability.lowDesc: Poor conditions for a visible crescent (e.g., Moon very low, setting too soon, or very young).
probability.mediumDesc: Borderline/mixed conditions; visibility depends on observer skill and local atmosphere.
probability.highDesc: Strong conditions (Moon higher, well separated from the Sun, older, stays up longer after sunset).

scholars.title: Scholarly Views on the Hijri Calendar
scholars.subtitle: Why Islamic scholars differ on when a new lunar month begins
scholars.intro: The Islamic (Hijri) calendar is a purely lunar calendar. Each month begins with the sighting of the new crescent moon (hilal). However, Islamic scholars have held different views for centuries on exactly how to determine that beginning — leading to situations where Ramadan, Eid, and other occasions may start on different days in different countries, or even within the same country — especially in geographically large nations where the crescent may be visible in one region but not another. Historically, though, each country has had a single religious authority (such as a mufti, sighting committee, or ministry of religious affairs) that issues a binding declaration for the entire country.
scholars.coreQuestion: The Core Question: How Is the New Moon Determined?
scholars.coreQuestionBody: All scholars agree that the Islamic month begins with the crescent moon — but they differ on several key points: Must the crescent be physically sighted with the naked eye, or can astronomical calculations suffice? If sighted, must it be seen locally, or does a confirmed sighting anywhere in the world count? Should optical instruments (telescopes, binoculars) be used? These questions have produced distinct scholarly positions, each rooted in Quranic verses, Hadith, and centuries of jurisprudential reasoning (ijtihad).

localSighting.title: Position 1: Local Sighting (Ikhtilaf al-Matali')
localSighting.body: This position holds that each region or country should rely on its own local crescent sighting. A sighting in Saudi Arabia, for example, does not obligate Muslims in Indonesia or Morocco to begin the month. The reasoning is that the moon's visibility varies by geographic location — the crescent may be visible in one part of the world but not yet in another.
localSighting.scholars: Imam al-Shafi'i, and the majority of the Shafi'i school. Also supported by many Hanbali scholars. Adopted by several Southeast Asian countries and by Egypt's Dar al-Ifta.
localSighting.practice: Countries like Malaysia, Indonesia, Brunei, and Egypt each conduct their own sighting and may start Ramadan on a different day than other countries. Egypt's Dar al-Ifta relies on local sighting confirmed by its own crescent observation committees across the country, and often announces dates that differ from Saudi Arabia by a day.

globalSighting.title: Position 2: Global Sighting (Ittihad al-Matali')
globalSighting.body: This position holds that if the crescent is reliably sighted anywhere in the world, all Muslims should begin the new month. The argument is based on the generality of the Prophet's hadith: 'Fast when you see it [the crescent] and break fast when you see it' — interpreting 'you' as the entire Muslim Ummah, not just a local community.
globalSighting.scholars: Predominant view among Hanafi scholars. Supported by some Hanbali scholars. Also adopted by the Fiqh Council of the Muslim World League in some rulings.
globalSighting.practice: Some Muslim communities in the West follow the earliest confirmed sighting globally (often from Saudi Arabia or the Middle East) to start their fast.

calculation.title: Position 3: Astronomical Calculation
calculation.body: A growing number of scholars and institutions argue that modern astronomical science can reliably predict when the crescent will be visible. They hold that calculations are at least as trustworthy as fallible human eyesight, and that the hadith about sighting was addressing a community without astronomical knowledge — not prohibiting the use of science. Some proponents distinguish between 'born moon' (conjunction) and 'visible crescent' calculations.
calculation.scholars: Supported by Yusuf al-Qaradawi, the Fiqh Council of North America (FCNA), the European Council for Fatwa and Research (ECFR), and many contemporary scholars. The FCNA officially adopted astronomical calculation in 2006.
calculation.practice: Turkey has used a purely calculated calendar (based on the Diyanet) for decades. The FCNA and ISNA in North America publish Ramadan and Eid dates years in advance based on calculations.

followSaudi.title: Position 4: Follow Saudi Arabia
followSaudi.body: Some communities choose to follow Saudi Arabia's announcement regardless of their own local sighting, arguing for unity with the land of the Two Holy Mosques (Haramain). This is not strictly a scholarly position on moon-sighting methodology, but rather a practical choice made by certain communities and organizations.
followSaudi.practice: Common among some diaspora communities who prefer a single reference point. Several countries in the Middle East and South Asia have historically aligned with Saudi announcements.

instruments.title: Naked Eye vs. Optical Instruments
instruments.body: Another point of debate is whether the crescent must be seen with the unaided naked eye or can be confirmed using telescopes, binoculars, or CCD imaging. Classical scholars naturally assumed naked-eye observation. Today, most sighting committees accept optical aids, but some traditionalist scholars insist only a naked-eye sighting fulfills the hadith. This can cause a one-day difference: a crescent too thin for the naked eye may be visible through a telescope.

whyDiffer.title: Why Do Countries Announce Different Dates?
whyDiffer.body: Even when two countries use the same general approach (e.g., both rely on sighting), they may still differ for several reasons:
whyDiffer.reason1: Geographic location — the crescent is visible in western longitudes before eastern ones on the same night.
whyDiffer.reason2: Weather and atmospheric conditions — clouds, dust, or haze can prevent sighting even when the moon is astronomically above the horizon.
whyDiffer.reason3: Criteria stringency — some committees accept a single witness testimony; others require multiple witnesses or corroborating evidence.
whyDiffer.reason4: Political considerations — some governments align with regional allies or make announcements based on diplomatic factors.
whyDiffer.reason5: Methodology mix — some countries use calculations to reject impossible sightings but still require a physical sighting for confirmation (a hybrid approach).

scholars.disclaimer: This page is for educational purposes only. It presents a simplified overview of scholarly positions and does not constitute a religious ruling (fatwa). Muslims are advised to follow their local Islamic authority or trusted scholarly body for determining the start of Islamic months.

about.title: About
about.privacyBody: Your privacy matters. This application is designed to work entirely in your browser:
about.privacyNoServer: No data is ever sent to a remote server — all date calculations and astronomical computations happen locally on your device.
about.privacyNoTracking: No analytics, tracking pixels, or third-party scripts are used.
about.privacyNoCookies: No cookies are stored. Your preferences (language, location, method) are kept in your browser's local storage and never shared.
about.privacyLocation: If you choose to share your location, it is used only for local sunset/moonset calculations and is never transmitted anywhere.
about.disclaimerBody: This tool is for informational and educational purposes only. It is not an official religious authority and should not be used as a substitute for local moon-sighting committees or official Hijri calendar announcements in your country. Crescent-visibility estimates are based on astronomical models and may differ from actual observed conditions.
about.openSourceBody: Hijri Calendar is free and open-source software. Contributions, bug reports, and suggestions are welcome.
about.ourResearchDesc: Our comprehensive survey of 15 Hijri month-start methods, with formulae, pseudocode, and citations from the academic literature
